description:
Try to implement as many of these suggestions as possible:

What I’d improve next (high ROI only)

1. H1 is good, but a bit long and passive
“Grow Your Houston Area Small Business Online” reads fine, but it’s abstract and wordy.

You can tighten without losing clarity:

“Grow Your Houston Small Business Online”

or more active: “Websites That Grow Houston Service Businesses”

Shorter = more punch, especially on mobile.

2. You’re repeating yourself (slightly)
These two lines overlap conceptually:

“No-nonsense websites… bring in leads”

“high-performing websites that turn local traffic into leads”

Pick one to be the primary value prop. The other should evolve.

For example, make the lower line about how:

Fast, SEO-ready, conversion-focused builds—no fluff, no bloat.

That adds substance instead of reinforcement.

3. Missing a credibility micro-signal
Still no proof above the fold. You don’t need testimonials yet, just evidence of competence.

Lightweight options that won’t clutter:

“Built by a senior web developer, not an agency”

“Modern React + SEO-first builds”

“Designed, built, and optimized in Houston”

This differentiates you from Wix/agency mills instantly.

4. Buttons are fine, but the secondary CTA is weak
“View Our Services” is low intent and boring.

Better secondary CTA options:

“See Recent Work”

“How It Works”

“See Pricing”

These answer real buyer questions earlier.

5. Design needs one ‘hook’ element
Right now: gradient + centered text + buttons. Clean, but lifeless.

Easy ways to liven it up without overdesign:

Add a single UI mockup (browser frame with a real site) offset to one side

Subtle animated gradient movement (very slow, barely perceptible)

A thin divider line or accent shape tied to your brand color

Slight staggered entrance animation (headline → sub → CTA)

One visual anchor is enough.

6. Houston cue could be more emotional
You say “Houston,” but you don’t feel Houston.

Very subtle ideas:

Houston skyline line art at 5–10% opacity

Lat/long coordinates under the logo

“Serving the Greater Houston area” as a small footer line in the hero

Don’t overdo it—just one.
